UNF poll: Most voters don't back abortion ban, 'Don't Say Gay' bills in Florida LegislatureSteve Patterson
 
| Florida Times-UnionBills to ban abortion after 15 weeks and restrict discussion of sexual orientation in elementary school lack support from most Florida voters despite making headway in Florida’s Legislature, University of North Florida pollsters have reported.The school’s Public Opinion Research Laboratory said a statewide survey of voters found 55 percent opposed the abortion bill the state’s House of Representatives approved last week, and opposition grew to 60 percent when people were told it didn’t make exceptions for victims of rape or incest.Thirty-four percent of the people surveyed supported the idea, according to a release from UNF.Legislation dubbed the “Don’t Say Gay” bill that passed Florida’s Senate was supported by just 40 percent of the voters questioned, while 49 percent of voters were against it.The bill, which would prohibit school districts from encouraging discussion about sexual orientation or gender identity in grades Kindergarten through 5, did get support from 54 percent of Republican voters, UNF political scientist Michael Binder, the research lab’s faculty director, noted in the release.The responses were part of a batch of survey questions that show gaps between what voters say they prefer and ideas that get attention in Tallahassee.The survey of 685 registered voters — picked to be representative of the state’s millions of likely voters — found 76 percent supported legalizing possession of small amounts of marijuana for recreational use by adults.And it reported that only 32 percent supported a proposed amendment to the state constitution requiring county school board candidates to run for office in partisan elections with party affiliations.Fort-nine percent said they opposed that idea and the rest didn’t know, the release said.“Often very little information is available for down ballot candidates—school board races in particular—and simply adding a party identifier will increase the partisan voting in those races,” Binder said in the release. “The amendment has pretty weak support among survey respondents at just over 30 percent, which seems to indicate Florida voters want to keep politics out of the education system.”People taking the survey were also asked whether they support or oppose legalizing sports and event betting for people age 21 or older.Half of those people were also told that tax money from that betting would be used to support education in Florida.Fifty percent said they supported the idea when there was no mention of education funding, but that rose to 60 percent when the funding language was added. The share of opponents dropped from 35 percent to 28 percent.“The stark differences in the two versions of the question shows just how important wording can be when it comes to public opinion,” Binder was quoted saying. “If people see a benefit for the state, such as increased funding for education, they’re more likely to support a variety of policies. One of the big reasons lotteries were legalized at the state level in the first place was that a large chunk of those revenues went toward education and online gambling supporters are simply following in those footsteps.”
